The food was excellent! We ordered the Shrimp and Grits, which were absolutely amazingâ€”10/10! We also had the classic breakfast, which I'd highly recommend if you're not feeling too adventurous.

Four of us enjoyed Sunday brunch! We cleaned our own plates and the extra fruit plate and table pancake plate. Iâ€™ll speak to the most delicious Shrimp & Grits Iâ€™ve ever had. That says everything as that and eggs Benedict are two of my faves to try everywhere and compare.
First, the grits were creamiest ever. The grilled shrimp was done perfectly, but the addition of soft, thin onion slices, bites of porkbelly, and sweet microgreens made every bite delicious. We were visiting Brooklyn, but our kids said they added Le Pistol to their top 5 now.

Two frenchies walk into a French brunch bistro in Brooklyn, and oh la la what could possibly go wrong?!

Le Pistol brunch in Brooklyn is a delightful mix of culinary excellence and cultural confusion. The food? Magnifique. The ambiance? Well, let's just say, they got some distinct French things wrong and some things very right.

Firstly, the servers were way too friendly. In a true French restaurant, you expect a healthy dose of disdain with your meal. Secondly, the size of the orange juices was laughable. In France, you would get a size able OJ, but here, it was more like a shot glass.

Paying $5 for half an orange seems excessive even for Brooklyn, especially as these oranges come from Orange County, theyâ€™re not even Champagne import (like us).

The breakfast toasts were a curious affair. Served deconstructed, we were essentially tasked with sandwich assembly. Perhaps the kitchen staff were channeling their inner French by making us work for our meal.

Halfway through our â€˜petitâ€™ toasts, we caved and ordered pancakes, hoping they'd arrive before dinner. To our relief, they were American-sized fluffy pancakes, a stark contrast to the expected deconstructed crepes.

Overall, Le Pistol gets an A+ for food and an F for French authenticityâ€”maybe minus the long wait for the food to arrive and being included in the labor of making brunch happen. So in that sense, a little taste of home. All blagues aside, Pistolet is a solid brunch option and  who needs Paris when you've got Brooklyn?
